LangChain's coding agent went from Top 30 to Top 5 on Terminal Bench 2.0 with just a harness change. This post discusses the team's approach to harness engineering. The goal of a harness is to mold the intelligence of a model for tasks you care about. Self-verification and tracing help a lot.

Prompt Caching 201 (10 minute read)

OpenAI published a detailed guide explaining how prompt caching reuses repeated prompt prefixes to skip prefill compute, reducing latency and input token costs. It outlines cache mechanics, routing considerations, KV reuse, and practical strategies for increasing cache hit rates in production workloads.

On Universe, Life, and AI (3 minute read)

Ivan Zhao frames AI as the latest "tool of life" after language, markets, and the internet. Humanity uses culture, capital, and computation to impose its values on an indifferent universe, and AI extends this by accelerating idea discovery and coordination. In this view, AI is not separate from life but a continuation of life organizing matter and energy through intelligence.

Amical launches open-source, privacy-focused AI dictation app (2 minute read)

Amical has launched an open-source AI dictation app that offers privacy-focused, on-device speech recognition using models like Whisper. Unique features include context-aware formatting, custom prompts, and local data storage with a cloud fallback option for less capable devices. Available for Mac and Windows, Amical plans to expand to mobile and integrate with broader AI ecosystems.

[AINews] Anthropic's Agent Autonomy study

Thereâ€™s a lot of small tidbits going on, with former guest Fei-Fei Liâ€™s World Labs and The Era of Experienceâ€™s David Silver both raising monster $1B rounds, and Anthropic officially blocking OpenClaw using Claude OAuth tokens (consistent with post-OpenCode policy), with OpenAI employees politely reminding everyone that theyâ€™re more than welcome to use OpenAI plans instead on the same day (complete coincidence, we are sure).

è¿‘æœŸä¸šç•ŒåŠ¨æ€é¢‘é¢‘ï¼šæé£é£ï¼ˆFei-Fei Liï¼‰çš„ World Labs å’Œ The Era of Experience çš„ å¤§å«Â·è¥¿å°”å¼—ï¼ˆDavid Silverï¼‰å‡å®Œæˆäº†å·¨é¢ 10 äº¿ç¾å…ƒèèµ„ï¼›Anthropic æ­£å¼é˜»æ­¢ OpenClaw ä½¿ç”¨ Claude çš„ OAuth ä»¤ç‰Œï¼ˆç¬¦åˆ OpenCode äº‹ä»¶åçš„æ”¿ç­–ï¼‰ï¼›åŒä¸€å¤©ï¼ŒOpenAI å‘˜å·¥åˆ™ç¤¼è²Œåœ°"æé†’"ä¼—äººï¼Œä»–ä»¬éå¸¸æ¬¢è¿ç”¨æˆ·ä½¿ç”¨ OpenAI çš„ä»˜è´¹æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼ˆçº¯å±å·§åˆï¼Œç¡®ä¿¡æ— ç–‘ï¼‰ã€‚

However, all that will pass. What weâ€™d highlight today is Anthropicâ€™s study of its own API usage patterns, Measuring AI agent autonomy in practice. As you might expect, most usage is coding, but you can start to go down the list of the other uses and pick off the next likely targets for agents:

ç„¶è€Œï¼Œè¿™äº›éƒ½å°†è¿‡å»ã€‚ä»Šå¤©æˆ‘ä»¬è¦é‡ç‚¹ä»‹ç»çš„æ˜¯ Anthropic å¯¹å…¶è‡ªèº« API ä½¿ç”¨æ¨¡å¼çš„ç ”ç©¶â€”â€”ã€ŠMeasuring AI agent autonomy in practiceã€‹ï¼ˆå®è·µä¸­æµ‹é‡ AI æ™ºèƒ½ä½“è‡ªä¸»æ€§ï¼‰ã€‚ä¸å‡ºæ‰€æ–™ï¼Œå¤§éƒ¨åˆ†ä½¿ç”¨é›†ä¸­åœ¨ç¼–ç¨‹é¢†åŸŸï¼Œä½†ä½ å¯ä»¥é¡ºç€åˆ—è¡¨æŸ¥çœ‹å…¶ä»–ç”¨é€”ï¼Œå¹¶æ‰¾å‡ºæ™ºèƒ½ä½“ä¸‹ä¸€ä¸ªå¯èƒ½æ”»å…‹çš„é¢†åŸŸï¼š

Most of the post is about Claude Code usage. We see Anthropicâ€™s side of the â€œincreasing autonomy storyâ€ - starting at 25 mins in Sept to over 45 mins in Jan, with a dip coinciding with the sudden 2x jump in userbase in Jan-Feb 2026, and then rebounding with the release of Opus 4.6.

è¿™ç¯‡æŠ¥å‘Šçš„å¤§éƒ¨åˆ†å†…å®¹å›´ç»• Claude Code çš„ä½¿ç”¨æƒ…å†µå±•å¼€ã€‚ä» Anthropic çš„è§†è§’ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬çœ‹åˆ°äº†"è‡ªä¸»æ€§æå‡"çš„æ•…äº‹â€”â€”ä» 9 æœˆçš„ 25 åˆ†é’Ÿåˆ° 1 æœˆçš„ 45 åˆ†é’Ÿä»¥ä¸Šï¼ŒæœŸé—´åœ¨ 2026 å¹´ 1-2 æœˆç”¨æˆ·åŸºæ•°çªç„¶ç¿»å€æ—¶å‡ºç°ä¸‹æ»‘ï¼Œéšåéšç€ Opus 4.6 çš„å‘å¸ƒè€Œåå¼¹ã€‚

This is a somewhat different but directionally similar story with the famous METR chart, which, as we explain in our upcoming podcast with them, because it picks the 50th percentile success rate of HUMAN EQUIVALENT HOURS (äººç±»ç­‰æ•ˆå·¥æ—¶) instead of the 99.9th percentile long tail autonomy of Claude Code autonomous execution, shows a very different (and volatile at the extremes) trend of almost 5 hours of human work done by agents:

è¿™ä¸è‘—åçš„ METR å›¾è¡¨å‘ˆç°çš„æ•…äº‹æœ‰æ‰€ä¸åŒï¼Œä½†æ–¹å‘ä¸€è‡´ã€‚æ­£å¦‚æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨å³å°†å‘å¸ƒçš„æ’­å®¢ä¸­è§£é‡Šçš„é‚£æ ·ï¼ŒMETR é€‰å–çš„æ˜¯ HUMAN EQUIVALENT HOURSï¼ˆäººç±»ç­‰æ•ˆå·¥æ—¶ï¼Œå³ä»»åŠ¡å¯¹äººç±»è€Œè¨€çš„éš¾åº¦ï¼‰çš„ç¬¬ 50 ç™¾åˆ†ä½æˆåŠŸç‡ï¼Œè€Œé Claude Code è‡ªä¸»æ‰§è¡Œçš„ 99.9 ç™¾åˆ†ä½é•¿å°¾è‡ªä¸»æ€§ï¼Œå› æ­¤å‘ˆç°å‡ºæˆªç„¶ä¸åŒçš„è¶‹åŠ¿ï¼ˆåœ¨æç«¯æƒ…å†µä¸‹æ³¢åŠ¨è¾ƒå¤§ï¼‰â€”â€”æ˜¾ç¤ºæ™ºèƒ½ä½“å¯å®Œæˆè¿‘ 5 å°æ—¶çš„äººç±»å·¥ä½œï¼š

as Anthropic notes:

æ­£å¦‚ Anthropic æ‰€æŒ‡å‡ºçš„ï¼š

The METR evaluation captures what a model is capable of in an idealized setting with no human interaction and no real-world consequences. Our measurements capture what happens in practice, where Claude pauses to ask for feedback and users interrupt. And METRâ€™s five-hour figure measures task difficultyâ€”how long the task would take a humanâ€”not how long the model actually runs.(alsoâ€¦Most Claude Code turns are short. The median turn lasts around 45 seconds, and this duration has fluctuated only slightly over the past few months (between 40 and 55 seconds). In fact, nearly every percentile below the 99th has remained relatively stable.

METR çš„è¯„ä¼°æ•æ‰çš„æ˜¯æ¨¡å‹åœ¨ç†æƒ³åŒ–ç¯å¢ƒï¼ˆæ— äººå·¥å¹²é¢„ã€æ— ç°å®åæœï¼‰ä¸‹çš„èƒ½åŠ›ä¸Šé™ã€‚è€Œæˆ‘ä»¬çš„æµ‹é‡åæ˜ çš„æ˜¯å®é™…æƒ…å†µï¼šClaude ä¼šæš‚åœå¹¶è¯¢é—®åé¦ˆï¼Œç”¨æˆ·ä¹Ÿä¼šè¿›è¡Œå¹²é¢„ã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼ŒMETR çš„äº”å°æ—¶æ•°æ®è¡¡é‡çš„æ˜¯ä»»åŠ¡éš¾åº¦â€”â€”å³äººç±»å®Œæˆè¯¥ä»»åŠ¡æ‰€éœ€çš„æ—¶é—´â€”â€”è€Œéæ¨¡å‹å®é™…è¿è¡Œçš„æ—¶é•¿ã€‚ï¼ˆå¦å¤–â€¦â€¦å¤§å¤šæ•° Claude Code çš„äº¤äº’å›åˆå¾ˆçŸ­ã€‚ä¸­ä½å›åˆæ—¶é•¿çº¦ä¸º 45 ç§’ï¼Œè¿‡å»å‡ ä¸ªæœˆé‡Œè¿™ä¸€æ—¶é•¿ä»…åœ¨ 40 è‡³ 55 ç§’é—´å°å¹…æ³¢åŠ¨ã€‚äº‹å®ä¸Šï¼Œ99 åˆ†ä½ä»¥ä¸‹çš„å‡ ä¹æ‰€æœ‰ç™¾åˆ†ä½éƒ½ä¿æŒç›¸å¯¹ç¨³å®šã€‚ï¼‰

The METR evaluation captures what a model is capable of in an idealized setting with no human interaction and no real-world consequences. Our measurements capture what happens in practice, where Claude pauses to ask for feedback and users interrupt. And METRâ€™s five-hour figure measures task difficultyâ€”how long the task would take a humanâ€”not how long the model actually runs.(alsoâ€¦Most Claude Code turns are short. The median turn lasts around 45 seconds, and this duration has fluctuated only slightly over the past few months (between 40 and 55 seconds). In fact, nearly every percentile below the 99th has remained relatively stable.

METR çš„è¯„ä¼°æ•æ‰çš„æ˜¯æ¨¡å‹åœ¨ç†æƒ³åŒ–ç¯å¢ƒï¼ˆæ— äººå·¥å¹²é¢„ã€æ— ç°å®åæœï¼‰ä¸‹çš„èƒ½åŠ›ä¸Šé™ã€‚è€Œæˆ‘ä»¬çš„æµ‹é‡åæ˜ çš„æ˜¯å®é™…æƒ…å†µï¼šClaude ä¼šæš‚åœå¹¶è¯¢é—®åé¦ˆï¼Œç”¨æˆ·ä¹Ÿä¼šè¿›è¡Œå¹²é¢„ã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼ŒMETR çš„äº”å°æ—¶æ•°æ®è¡¡é‡çš„æ˜¯ä»»åŠ¡éš¾åº¦â€”â€”å³äººç±»å®Œæˆè¯¥ä»»åŠ¡æ‰€éœ€çš„æ—¶é—´â€”â€”è€Œéæ¨¡å‹å®é™…è¿è¡Œçš„æ—¶é•¿ã€‚ï¼ˆå¦å¤–â€¦â€¦å¤§å¤šæ•° Claude Code çš„äº¤äº’å›åˆå¾ˆçŸ­ã€‚ä¸­ä½å›åˆæ—¶é•¿çº¦ä¸º 45 ç§’ï¼Œè¿‡å»å‡ ä¸ªæœˆé‡Œè¿™ä¸€æ—¶é•¿ä»…åœ¨ 40 è‡³ 55 ç§’é—´å°å¹…æ³¢åŠ¨ã€‚äº‹å®ä¸Šï¼Œ99 åˆ†ä½ä»¥ä¸‹çš„å‡ ä¹æ‰€æœ‰ç™¾åˆ†ä½éƒ½ä¿æŒç›¸å¯¹ç¨³å®šã€‚ï¼‰

Enough said. Because Anthropic has full access to Claude Code telemetry (é¥æµ‹æ•°æ®), there are other autonomy measures nobody else has. For exampleâ€¦ new users start off with 20% auto-approve, and increase to >50% over time with experience

è¯´äº†è¿™ä¹ˆå¤šã€‚ç”±äº Anthropic æ‹¥æœ‰ Claude Code telemetryï¼ˆé¥æµ‹æ•°æ®ï¼‰çš„å®Œæ•´è®¿é—®æƒé™ï¼Œä»–ä»¬æ‹¥æœ‰å…¶ä»–æœºæ„æ— æ³•è·å–çš„è‡ªä¸»æ€§æŒ‡æ ‡ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚â€¦â€¦æ–°ç”¨æˆ·åˆå§‹çš„è‡ªåŠ¨æ‰¹å‡†ç‡ï¼ˆauto-approveï¼‰ä¸º 20%ï¼Œä½†éšç€ç»éªŒç§¯ç´¯ä¼šé€æ¸å¢é•¿è‡³ 50% ä»¥ä¸Šã€‚

â€¦although they do also interrupt it almost twice as often:

Introduction & Guest Profiles

Tickets for AIE Miami and AIE Europe are live, with first wave speakers announced!

AIE è¿ˆé˜¿å¯†å’ŒAIE æ¬§æ´²çš„é—¨ç¥¨ç°å·²å¼€å”®ï¼Œé¦–æ‰¹æ¼”è®²å˜‰å®¾åå•å·²å…¬å¸ƒï¼

From pioneering software-defined networking to backing many of the most aggressive AI model companies of this cycle, Martin Casado and Sarah Wang sit at the center of the capital, compute, and talent arms race reshaping the tech industry. As partners at a16z investing across infrastructure and growth, they've watched venture and growth blur, model labs turn dollars into capability at unprecedented speed, and startups raise nine-figure rounds before monetization.

Martin and Sarah join us to unpack the new financing playbook for AI: why today's rounds are really compute contracts in disguise, how the "raise â†’ train â†’ ship â†’ raise bigger" flywheel works, and whether foundation model companies can outspend the entire app ecosystem built on top of them.

  • The capital flywheel: how model labs translate funding directly into capability gains, then into revenue growth measured in weeks, not years
  • Why venture and growth have merged: $100Mâ€“$1B hybrid rounds, strategic investors, compute negotiations, and complex deal structures

æ‘˜è¦: æ–‡ç« æå‡ºï¼Œéšç€AIå’Œæœºå™¨äººæŠ€æœ¯ä½¿è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–æ—¥ç›Šçµæ´»ï¼Œæœªæ¥åˆ¶é€ ä¸šä¸ç§‘ç ”ç­‰é¢†åŸŸå¯èƒ½æ¶Œç°ç±»ä¼¼AWSçš„"ä¸‡ç‰©å³æœåŠ¡"æ¨¡å¼â€”â€”é€šè¿‡å¤§è§„æ¨¡å…±äº«åŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½ä¸æ™ºèƒ½è°ƒåº¦ï¼Œä¸ºå°æ‰¹é‡ã€å¤šæ ·åŒ–éœ€æ±‚æä¾›ä½æˆæœ¬ã€é«˜æ•ˆç‡çš„å®šåˆ¶åŒ–ç”Ÿäº§ï¼Œæ‰“ç ´ä¼ ç»Ÿå¤§è§„æ¨¡ç”Ÿäº§æ‰èƒ½é™æœ¬çš„å±€é™ã€‚

åŸæ ‡é¢˜: Is the Future â€œAWS for Everythingâ€?

A theme running through my book is the idea that efficiency improvements, and the various methods for making products cheaper over time, have historically been dependent on some degree of repetition, on running your production process over and over again. Higher production volume means larger, more efficient factories. It means more opportunities to use dedicated, high-speed, continuous process production equipment, or to implement efficiency-improving methods like Design for Manufacturing (DFM, é¢å‘åˆ¶é€ çš„è®¾è®¡) or Statistical Process Control (SPC, ç»Ÿè®¡è¿‡ç¨‹æ§åˆ¶). It means more incentive to develop new, better production technology. It means more opportunities to fall down the learning curve (å­¦ä¹ æ›²çº¿). The list goes on.

è´¯ç©¿æˆ‘è¿™æœ¬ä¹¦çš„ä¸€ä¸ªä¸»é¢˜æ˜¯ï¼Œæ•ˆç‡æå‡ä»¥åŠéšæ—¶é—´æ¨ç§»é™ä½äº§å“æˆæœ¬çš„å„ç§æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå†å²ä¸Šéƒ½ä¾èµ–äºä¸€å®šç¨‹åº¦çš„é‡å¤æ€§ï¼Œå³åå¤è¿è¡Œä½ çš„ç”Ÿäº§æµç¨‹ã€‚æ›´é«˜çš„äº§é‡æ„å‘³ç€æ›´å¤§ã€æ›´é«˜æ•ˆçš„å·¥å‚ï¼›æ„å‘³ç€æ›´å¤šæœºä¼šä½¿ç”¨ä¸“ç”¨çš„é«˜é€Ÿè¿ç»­ç”Ÿäº§è®¾å¤‡ï¼Œæˆ–å®æ–½å¦‚é¢å‘åˆ¶é€ çš„è®¾è®¡ï¼ˆDFMï¼‰æˆ–ç»Ÿè®¡è¿‡ç¨‹æ§åˆ¶ï¼ˆSPCï¼‰ç­‰æé«˜æ•ˆç‡çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼›æ„å‘³ç€å¼€å‘æ–°çš„ã€æ›´ä¼˜ç”Ÿäº§æŠ€æœ¯çš„åŠ¨åŠ›æ›´å¼ºï¼›æ„å‘³ç€æ›´å¤šæœºä¼šæ²¿å­¦ä¹ æ›²çº¿ä¸‹é™ã€‚è¿™æ ·çš„ä¾‹å­ä¸èƒœæšä¸¾ã€‚

If youâ€™re only going to run your process once, or just a handful of times, these opportunities are considerably narrowed. Itâ€™s obviously hard to justify the time and effort it takes to design a really efficient production process or invent some new manufacturing equipment if that process is constantly changing.

å¦‚æœä½ åªæ‰“ç®—è¿è¡Œä¸€æ¬¡æµç¨‹ï¼Œæˆ–ä»…ä»…è¿è¡Œå°‘æ•°å‡ æ¬¡ï¼Œè¿™äº›æœºä¼šå°±ä¼šå¤§å¤§ç¼©å°ã€‚å¦‚æœæµç¨‹ä¸æ–­å˜åŒ–ï¼Œæ˜¾ç„¶å¾ˆéš¾è¯æ˜æŠ•å…¥æ—¶é—´å’Œç²¾åŠ›å»è®¾è®¡ä¸€ä¸ªçœŸæ­£é«˜æ•ˆçš„ç”Ÿäº§æµç¨‹æˆ–å‘æ˜ä¸€äº›æ–°çš„åˆ¶é€ è®¾å¤‡æ˜¯åˆç†çš„ã€‚

An example of this playing out in practice is the different cost trends of cars vs. car repair. In inflation-adjusted (ç»é€šèƒ€è°ƒæ•´çš„) terms, cars have steadily gotten cheaper over time. The cost of car repair, on the other hand, has steadily gotten more expensive, rising mostly at the rate of overall wages (and recently, even faster).

è¿™ä¸€ç°è±¡åœ¨å®è·µä¸­çš„ä¸€ä¸ªä¾‹å­æ˜¯æ±½è½¦ä¸æ±½è½¦ç»´ä¿®çš„ä¸åŒæˆæœ¬è¶‹åŠ¿ã€‚æŒ‰ç»é€šèƒ€è°ƒæ•´åçš„ä»·æ ¼è®¡ç®—ï¼Œæ±½è½¦éšæ—¶é—´æ¨ç§»ç¨³æ­¥é™ä»·ï¼›è€Œå¦ä¸€æ–¹é¢ï¼Œæ±½è½¦ç»´ä¿®æˆæœ¬å´ç¨³æ­¥ä¸Šæ¶¨ï¼Œæ¶¨å¹…åŸºæœ¬ä¸æ•´ä½“å·¥èµ„æ°´å¹³åŒæ­¥ï¼ˆæœ€è¿‘ç”šè‡³æ›´å¿«ï¼‰ã€‚

Much of this difference comes down to the nature of the processes at work. Cars are manufactured via a repetitive, high-volume process that spits out nearly identical models by the hundreds of thousands or millions. Car manufacturers can justify spending billions of dollars designing a new model of car and the process for making it, because that cost will get spread out over a huge number of cars. Repairing a damaged car, on the other hand, is different: for a given model, any given repair process will be run a much smaller number of times, or maybe only once (since cars might get damaged in accidents in unique ways). A repair facility will need to accommodate a huge number of different models and model years, each damaged in different ways. Thereâ€™s much less opportunity to design an efficient, highly automated repair process.

è¿™ç§å·®å¼‚å¾ˆå¤§ç¨‹åº¦ä¸Šæºäºæ‰€æ¶‰åŠæµç¨‹çš„æ€§è´¨ã€‚æ±½è½¦é€šè¿‡é‡å¤çš„å¤§æ‰¹é‡æµç¨‹åˆ¶é€ ï¼Œä»¥æ•°åä¸‡æˆ–æ•°ç™¾ä¸‡çš„æ•°é‡äº§å‡ºå‡ ä¹ç›¸åŒçš„è½¦å‹ã€‚æ±½è½¦åˆ¶é€ å•†å¯ä»¥è¯æ˜èŠ±è´¹æ•°åäº¿ç¾å…ƒè®¾è®¡æ–°è½¦å‹åŠå…¶åˆ¶é€ æµç¨‹æ˜¯åˆç†çš„ï¼Œå› ä¸ºè¿™äº›æˆæœ¬ä¼šåˆ†æ‘Šåˆ°å¤§é‡çš„æ±½è½¦ä¸Šã€‚è€Œä¿®ç†æŸåçš„æ±½è½¦åˆ™ä¸åŒï¼šå¯¹äºç‰¹å®šè½¦å‹ï¼Œä»»ä½•ç‰¹å®šçš„ç»´ä¿®æµç¨‹è¿è¡Œçš„æ¬¡æ•°éƒ½è¦å°‘å¾—å¤šï¼Œæˆ–è®¸åªè¿è¡Œä¸€æ¬¡ï¼ˆå› ä¸ºæ±½è½¦åœ¨äº‹æ•…ä¸­å—æŸçš„æ–¹å¼å¯èƒ½æ˜¯ç‹¬ç‰¹çš„ï¼‰ã€‚ç»´ä¿®è®¾æ–½éœ€è¦é€‚åº”å¤§é‡ä¸åŒçš„è½¦å‹å’Œå¹´ä»½ï¼Œæ¯è¾†è½¦å—æŸæ–¹å¼å„ä¸ç›¸åŒã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œè®¾è®¡é«˜æ•ˆçš„ã€é«˜åº¦è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–çš„ç»´ä¿®æµç¨‹çš„æœºä¼šå°±å°‘å¾—å¤šã€‚

There are some complications to this basic pattern â€” the Toyota Production System (TPS, ä¸°ç”°ç”Ÿäº§ç³»ç»Ÿ) and its descendents were designed to get mass-production-style benefits for a much more variable production process by making that process more flexible â€” but they donâ€™t change the fundamental logic.

è¿™ä¸€åŸºæœ¬æ¨¡å¼å­˜åœ¨ä¸€äº›å¤æ‚æƒ…å†µâ€”â€”ä¸°ç”°ç”Ÿäº§ç³»ç»Ÿï¼ˆTPSï¼‰åŠå…¶åç»§è€…æ—¨åœ¨é€šè¿‡æé«˜æµç¨‹çš„çµæ´»æ€§ï¼Œä¸ºå˜åŒ–æ€§æ›´å¤§çš„ç”Ÿäº§æµç¨‹å¸¦æ¥å¤§è§„æ¨¡ç”Ÿäº§å¼çš„æ•ˆç›Šâ€”â€”ä½†è¿™å¹¶æœªæ”¹å˜å…¶åŸºæœ¬é€»è¾‘ã€‚

Thus, for things that we can repetitively produce in very large volumes â€” cars, transistors (æ™¶ä½“ç®¡), LCD screens (æ¶²æ™¶æ˜¾ç¤ºå±), corn â€” weâ€™ve gotten good at making them very cheaply. Things produced in much smaller volumes, or where we need to adapt our process on the fly based on the specific situation, are much harder to produce cheaply. One way of thinking about services, which tend to get more expensive in inflation-adjusted terms over time, is that theyâ€™re things which generally require a lot of situation-specific adaptation, and canâ€™t be produced via some high-volume, highly repetitive process.

å› æ­¤ï¼Œå¯¹äºé‚£äº›æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å¤§è§„æ¨¡é‡å¤ç”Ÿäº§çš„ä¸œè¥¿â€”â€”æ±½è½¦ã€æ™¶ä½“ç®¡ã€æ¶²æ™¶æ˜¾ç¤ºå±ã€ç‰ç±³â€”â€”æˆ‘ä»¬å·²ç»æ“…é•¿ä»¥å¾ˆä½çš„æˆæœ¬åˆ¶é€ å®ƒä»¬ã€‚è€Œå¯¹äºäº§é‡å°å¾—å¤šçš„ä¸œè¥¿ï¼Œæˆ–éœ€è¦æ ¹æ®å…·ä½“æƒ…å†µå³æ—¶è°ƒæ•´æµç¨‹çš„ä¸œè¥¿ï¼Œå°±å¾ˆéš¾ä½æˆæœ¬ç”Ÿäº§ã€‚ä¸€ç§ç†è§£æœåŠ¡çš„æ–¹å¼ï¼ˆæœåŠ¡åœ¨ç»é€šèƒ€è°ƒæ•´åå¾€å¾€éšæ—¶é—´æ¨ç§»å˜å¾—æ›´è´µï¼‰æ˜¯ï¼šå®ƒä»¬é€šå¸¸éœ€è¦å¤§é‡é’ˆå¯¹å…·ä½“æƒ…å¢ƒçš„é€‚åº”ï¼Œæ— æ³•é€šè¿‡æŸç§å¤§æ‰¹é‡ã€é«˜åº¦é‡å¤æ€§çš„æµç¨‹æ¥ç”Ÿäº§ã€‚

An important aspect of this is automation. Iâ€™m fond of pointing out that itâ€™s generally possible to build a machine to perform any particular task (and it has been for quite some time). If youâ€™re going to do some task thousands or millions of times, itâ€™s long been possible to automate that task with some sort of dedicated machine. (People skeptical of humanoid robots (äººå½¢æœºå™¨äºº) are very fond of pointing out how this sort of hard automation is far more efficient than a human-shaped robot at doing some task.) The challenge with automation has historically been flexibility: creating a machine that can make adjustments on the fly, perhaps changing the sequence of tasks completely as the situation changes, the way a human can. Even if the hardware itself can be used to perform a variety of different tasks, information processing capabilities have been limited; it has taken a lot of time and effort to get any particular automated process working, which could only be justified if those costs could be amortized over a sufficiently large volume. This is why the car industry has by far been the biggest user of industrial robots historically, as they have the right combination of very high production volumes, and frequent (but not too frequent) process changes (since models change yearly).

è¿™é‡Œçš„ä¸€ä¸ªé‡è¦æ–¹é¢æ˜¯è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–ã€‚æˆ‘å–œæ¬¢æŒ‡å‡ºï¼Œåˆ¶é€ ä¸€å°æœºå™¨æ¥æ‰§è¡Œä»»ä½•ç‰¹å®šä»»åŠ¡é€šå¸¸æ€»æ˜¯å¯èƒ½çš„ï¼ˆè€Œä¸”é•¿æœŸä»¥æ¥ä¸€ç›´å¦‚æ­¤ï¼‰ã€‚å¦‚æœä½ è¦æ‰§è¡ŒæŸé¡¹ä»»åŠ¡æ•°åƒæ¬¡æˆ–æ•°ç™¾ä¸‡æ¬¡ï¼Œé•¿æœŸä»¥æ¥å°±æœ‰å¯èƒ½ç”¨æŸç§ä¸“ç”¨æœºå™¨å°†å…¶è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–ã€‚ï¼ˆæ€€ç–‘äººå½¢æœºå™¨äººçš„äººå¾ˆå–œæ¬¢æŒ‡å‡ºï¼Œè¿™ç§ç¡¬è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–åœ¨å®ŒæˆæŸäº›ä»»åŠ¡æ—¶è¿œæ¯”äººå½¢æœºå™¨äººé«˜æ•ˆã€‚ï¼‰å†å²ä¸Šï¼Œè‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–çš„æŒ‘æˆ˜åœ¨äºçµæ´»æ€§ï¼šåˆ›é€ ä¸€å°èƒ½å¤Ÿå³æ—¶è°ƒæ•´ã€å¯èƒ½éšç€æƒ…å†µå˜åŒ–å®Œå…¨æ”¹å˜ä»»åŠ¡é¡ºåºçš„æœºå™¨ï¼Œå°±åƒäººç±»é‚£æ ·ã€‚å³ä½¿ç¡¬ä»¶æœ¬èº«å¯ç”¨äºæ‰§è¡Œå„ç§ä¸åŒçš„ä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œä¿¡æ¯å¤„ç†èƒ½åŠ›ä¹Ÿæœ‰é™ï¼›è®©ä»»ä½•ç‰¹å®šçš„è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–æµç¨‹è¿è¡Œèµ·æ¥éƒ½éœ€è¦å¤§é‡æ—¶é—´å’Œç²¾åŠ›ï¼Œåªæœ‰å°†è¿™äº›æˆæœ¬åˆ†æ‘Šåˆ°è¶³å¤Ÿå¤§çš„äº§é‡ä¸Šæ‰æ˜¯åˆç†çš„ã€‚è¿™å°±æ˜¯ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆæ±½è½¦è¡Œä¸šè¿„ä»Šä¸ºæ­¢ä¸€ç›´æ˜¯å·¥ä¸šæœºå™¨äººçš„æœ€å¤§ç”¨æˆ·ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒä»¬å…¼å…·éå¸¸é«˜çš„äº§é‡å’Œé¢‘ç¹ï¼ˆä½†ä¸è¿‡åˆ†é¢‘ç¹ï¼‰çš„æµç¨‹å˜æ›´ï¼ˆå› ä¸ºè½¦å‹æ¯å¹´éƒ½åœ¨å˜åŒ–ï¼‰ã€‚

But this is changing: automation technology is getting more and more flexible. Computer vision (è®¡ç®—æœºè§†è§‰) has advanced, billions of dollars are being poured into developing humanoid robots, and a panoply of AI technologies are making it possible for an automated system to flexibly respond in a highly variable environment. Self-driving cars are one example. Being able to drive between any given two points, responding to situations or disruptions as they appear â€” traffic lights, pedestrians, other cars â€” is the exact sort of thing that automation historically has been very bad at, but that technology is now chipping away at.

ä½†è¿™ç§æƒ…å†µæ­£åœ¨æ”¹å˜ï¼šè‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–æŠ€æœ¯æ­£å˜å¾—è¶Šæ¥è¶Šçµæ´»ã€‚è®¡ç®—æœºè§†è§‰å·²ç»è¿›æ­¥ï¼Œæ•°åäº¿ç¾å…ƒæ­£è¢«æŠ•å…¥åˆ°äººå½¢æœºå™¨äººçš„å¼€å‘ä¸­ï¼Œå„ç§äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½æŠ€æœ¯æ­£ä½¿è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–ç³»ç»Ÿèƒ½å¤Ÿåœ¨é«˜åº¦å˜åŒ–çš„ç¯å¢ƒä¸­çµæ´»å“åº”ã€‚è‡ªåŠ¨é©¾é©¶æ±½è½¦å°±æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªä¾‹å­ã€‚èƒ½å¤Ÿåœ¨ä»»æ„ä¸¤ç‚¹ä¹‹é—´é©¾é©¶ï¼Œå¯¹å‡ºç°çš„æƒ…å†µæˆ–å¹²æ‰°â€”â€”äº¤é€šä¿¡å·ç¯ã€è¡Œäººã€å…¶ä»–è½¦è¾†â€”â€”åšå‡ºååº”ï¼Œè¿™æ­£æ˜¯å†å²ä¸Šè‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–ä¸€ç›´å¾ˆä¸æ“…é•¿çš„äº‹æƒ…ï¼Œä½†æŠ€æœ¯ç°åœ¨æ­£åœ¨é€æ­¥æ”»å…‹è¿™ä¸€éš¾é¢˜ã€‚

As automation technology gets better and better, I have been thinking about how it will get pushed into areas requiring low-volume production or situation-specific adaptation that previously have been resistant to it. One potential trajectory is that with better, more flexible automation, â€œminimum efficient scaleâ€ (æœ€å°æœ‰æ•ˆè§„æ¨¡) â€” the size of an operation you need to be competitive â€” shrinks. With sufficiently capable robots, for instance, it might become possible to efficiently produce things in really small-footprint, low-overhead factories. The idea of â€œmicrofactoriesâ€ (å¾®å‹å·¥å‚) is something people are enthusiastic about: you often see it in various prefab construction startups, but that excitement has spread elsewhere. The premise of the (now-defunct) EV startup Arrival was building cars using these sorts of highly flexible microfactories.

éšç€è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–æŠ€æœ¯è¶Šæ¥è¶Šå¥½ï¼Œæˆ‘ä¸€ç›´åœ¨æ€è€ƒå®ƒå°†å¦‚ä½•è¢«æ¨è¿›åˆ°ä»¥å‰æŠ—æ‹’å®ƒçš„é¢†åŸŸâ€”â€”é‚£äº›éœ€è¦å°æ‰¹é‡ç”Ÿäº§æˆ–é’ˆå¯¹å…·ä½“æƒ…å¢ƒé€‚åº”çš„é¢†åŸŸã€‚ä¸€ç§å¯èƒ½çš„è½¨è¿¹æ˜¯ï¼Œæœ‰äº†æ›´å¥½ã€æ›´çµæ´»çš„è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–ï¼Œ"æœ€å°æœ‰æ•ˆè§„æ¨¡"ï¼ˆä¿æŒç«äº‰åŠ›æ‰€éœ€çš„è¿è¥è§„æ¨¡ï¼‰ä¼šç¼©å°ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œæœ‰äº†èƒ½åŠ›è¶³å¤Ÿçš„æœºå™¨äººï¼Œå¯èƒ½å¯ä»¥åœ¨å åœ°é¢ç§¯å¾ˆå°ã€ç®¡ç†è´¹ç”¨ä½çš„å·¥å‚é‡Œé«˜æ•ˆç”Ÿäº§ä¸œè¥¿ã€‚"å¾®å‹å·¥å‚"è¿™ä¸ªæ¦‚å¿µè®©äººä»¬å¾ˆå…´å¥‹ï¼šä½ ç»å¸¸åœ¨å„ç§é¢„åˆ¶å»ºç­‘åˆåˆ›å…¬å¸ä¸­çœ‹åˆ°å®ƒï¼Œä½†è¿™ç§çƒ­æƒ…å·²ç»è”“å»¶åˆ°å…¶ä»–åœ°æ–¹ã€‚ï¼ˆç°å·²å€’é—­çš„ï¼‰ç”µåŠ¨æ±½è½¦åˆåˆ›å…¬å¸Arrivalçš„å‰æå°±æ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨è¿™ç§é«˜åº¦çµæ´»çš„å¾®å‹å·¥å‚æ¥åˆ¶é€ æ±½è½¦ã€‚

But another possible trajectory is in the opposite direction: large-scale, highly efficient production operations which capture significant economies of scale (è§„æ¨¡ç»æµ), but which produce a very wide range of outputs. Factories producing millions of different products in low volumes, or even quantities of one. Iâ€™m tentatively calling this idea â€œAWS for everything.â€

ä½†å¦ä¸€ç§å¯èƒ½çš„è½¨è¿¹åˆ™æœç›¸åæ–¹å‘å‘å±•ï¼šå¤§è§„æ¨¡ã€é«˜æ•ˆçš„ç”Ÿäº§è¿è¥ï¼Œæ—¢èƒ½è·å¾—æ˜¾è‘—çš„è§„æ¨¡ç»æµï¼Œåˆèƒ½ç”Ÿäº§éå¸¸å¹¿æ³›çš„äº§å‡ºã€‚å·¥å‚ä»¥ä½äº§é‡ç”Ÿäº§æ•°ç™¾ä¸‡ç§ä¸åŒçš„äº§å“ï¼Œç”šè‡³äº§é‡ä¸ºä¸€ã€‚æˆ‘æš‚æ—¶å°†è¿™ä¸ªæ¦‚å¿µç§°ä¸º"ä¸‡ç‰©AWS"ï¼ˆAWS for everythingï¼‰ã€‚

AWS and flexible automation

AWS (Amazon Web Services) is Amazonâ€™s cloud computing business. The idea of it (and of other similar offerings like Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud Platform) is that instead of needing to set up your own computing infrastructure to do things like host a website or store large amounts of data, you can just rent it from Amazon. Amazon builds the data centers (æ•°æ®ä¸­å¿ƒ), sets up the servers, and creates the software tools and infrastructure that other people can use to set up and manage their computing needs.

Making this work as a business demands a huge amount of expensive infrastructure; even before AI, Amazon and other cloud computing companies spent a huge amount of money building data centers in various regions. But as Ben Thompson notes, AWS â€œbenefits tremendously from economies of scale.â€ The more customers AWS has, the more efficiently it can use its infrastructure, similar to how electric utilities wanted lots of customers to reduce demand variability and achieve higher utilization rates. Thus with AWS you get a highly variable output â€” millions of different websites and computing tasks â€” supported by large-scale infrastructure investments. You can very quickly use Amazonâ€™s infrastructure to perform whatever computing task youâ€™re interested in, from hosting a small website to processing terabytes of data, without needing to build or operate any of that infrastructure yourself.

This same basic logic applies to physical automation. If you have machinery or equipment that can perform different sorts of tasks or produce a variety of different goods, and an effective software control layer (è½¯ä»¶æ§åˆ¶å±‚) that can tell each piece of equipment what it should be doing and where material should be routed, you can automatically produce a very large variety of different things. And the larger your operations, the lower your marginal costs (è¾¹é™…æˆæœ¬) of production: the more you produce, the greater your equipment utilization rate, and the more you can capture other economies of scale, such as using more efficient high-volume equipment.

Historically setting up this sort of highly automated, highly flexible production operation has been limited by the fact that setting up any particular automated process took a great deal of time and effort, and the technology didnâ€™t exist for that automation to respond flexibly to a highly variable environment. So automated production lines, even ones that used flexible technology like robotics (æœºå™¨äººæŠ€æœ¯), could only be justified for high-volume production, and the range of variation they could accommodate was fairly limited.

But as automation and AI get better, this becomes much less true. If your software is smart enough, and your equipment flexible enough, you can set up some new process to produce some new widget on the fly, automatically working out what the process steps need to be and how to route the material through the various machines, without needing to take the time and effort to dial it in that was required historically. And if your volumes are high enough â€” if youâ€™re producing enough different widgets, each with its route through a sequence of machines, sharing processing steps where possible â€” your costs for each individual unit of production might be very low indeed, even as you produce a wide variety of different things. So I can imagine having very large-volume production operations, which obtain large economies of scale and produce a wide variety of different outputs. Huge warehouses filled with all sorts of different machines, materials, parts, and components being routed between them, paths and tasks changing on the fly, a panoply of different goods rolling off the equivalent of the assembly line, each one sent to its final destination by low-cost, small-scale delivery vehicles like drones or Austin Vernonâ€™s pallet EVs. Customers could spin up production on this rented equipment and start producing whatever they wanted without having to build their own factory. These sorts of operations wouldnâ€™t displace traditional mass-production style processes (which will still have a substantial cost advantage), but would exist alongside them.

AWS for everything

You can see the seeds of this â€œAWS for everythingâ€ concept in some businesses that exist today. In manufacturing there are fabricators that specialize in high-mix production (é«˜æ··åˆç”Ÿäº§) like SendCutSend, OSH Cut, or JLCPCB. You send your part design to SendCutSend: their software automatically checks to see if it can be fabricated using their equipment (laser cutters (æ¿€å…‰åˆ‡å‰²æœº), CNC machines (æ•°æ§æœºåºŠ), etc.), and they send you back the part a few days later. According to SendCutSendâ€™s founder Jim Belosic, this model only works because of economies of scale, being able to efficiently spread the costs of their millions of dollars of equipment. As he said on Tool or Die:

The key with high mix is that it actually works at scale. The larger volume of high mix, the easier things get...Especially with sheet cutting. With sheet cutting, the software side of us, it allows us to take hundreds of different customers, with a quantity of one part each, and put them onto a sheet, like tetris, nested all together, and run it all at once. So we only do one setup, for potentially dozens or hundreds of customers, we do one load into the machine, we only retrieve the material once. And we have really good sheet utilization, we have almost no scrap. Itâ€™s probably one of the lowest in the industry.

It doesnâ€™t work though, when you only do a few. If I was to run one of those customers at a time, weâ€™d be bankrupt.

SendCutSend has grown rapidly â€” founded in 2018, they recently passed $100 million in annual revenue â€” but they still work hard to maintain flexibility, using equipment that doesnâ€™t require months of downtime to reprogram or configure when processes change. Theyâ€™re also expanding their offerings. They started with laser cutting, later added CNC machining, and now offer welding of single parts. You can imagine that as automation gets better and better, this sort of business model could continue to be extended, going to multi-part welding, assembly, and eventually entirely finished goods.

And itâ€™s not just manufacturing where this sort of production model might emerge. I was inspired to write this essay after reading a really great essay about lab automation at Owl Posting, speculating that various lab automation startups might converge on being â€œAWS for biotechâ€: large, automated labs that can spread the costs of their automation over a large number of experiments run for different customers. Right now much of this sort of lab work isnâ€™t automated, not because itâ€™s not possible to automate but because itâ€™s not repeated enough to be worth it in any particular lab. Centralize all those experiments in one place, and maybe that changes:

è€Œä¸”ï¼Œè¿™ç§ç”Ÿäº§æ¨¡å¼å¯èƒ½å‡ºç°çš„é¢†åŸŸä¸ä»…ä»…æ˜¯åˆ¶é€ ä¸šã€‚æˆ‘è¯»åˆ°Owl Postingä¸Šä¸€ç¯‡å…³äºå®éªŒå®¤è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–çš„ç²¾å½©æ–‡ç« åï¼Œå—åˆ°å¯å‘å†™ä¸‹äº†è¿™ç¯‡æ–‡ç« ã€‚è¯¥æ–‡ç« æ¨æµ‹ï¼Œå„ç§å®éªŒå®¤è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–åˆåˆ›å…¬å¸å¯èƒ½ä¼šè¶‹åŒäºæˆä¸º"ç”Ÿç‰©ç§‘æŠ€AWS"ï¼šå¤§å‹è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–å®éªŒå®¤ï¼Œå¯ä»¥å°†è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–æˆæœ¬åˆ†æ‘Šåˆ°ä¸ºä¸åŒå®¢æˆ·è¿è¡Œçš„å¤§é‡å®éªŒä¸­ã€‚ç›®å‰ï¼Œè¿™ç±»å®éªŒå®¤å·¥ä½œä¸­çš„å¤§éƒ¨åˆ†è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–ï¼Œä¸æ˜¯å› ä¸ºä¸å¯èƒ½è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯å› ä¸ºåœ¨ä»»ä½•ç‰¹å®šå®éªŒå®¤ä¸­é‡å¤æ¬¡æ•°éƒ½ä¸å¤Ÿå¤šï¼Œä¸å€¼å¾—è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–ã€‚æŠŠæ‰€æœ‰è¿™äº›å®éªŒé›†ä¸­åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªåœ°æ–¹ï¼Œä¹Ÿè®¸æƒ…å†µå°±ä¼šæ”¹å˜ï¼š

If you are to accept that lab centralization (as in, cloud labs) means you can most efficiently use lab roboticsâ€”which feels like a pretty uncontroversial argumentâ€”it also means that the further you lean into this, the more able you are to vertically integrate upstream. If youâ€™re running enough experiments such that your robots are constantly humming, you can justify producing your own reagents. If youâ€™re producing your own reagents, your per-experiment costs drop. If your per-experiment costs drop, you can offer lower prices. If you offer lower prices, you attract more demand. If you attract more demand, your robots stay even busier. If your robots stay even busier, you can justify producing even more of your own inputs. And so on, ad infinitum, until you devour the entirety of the market, and the game of biology becomes extraordinarily cheap and easy for everyone to play in.

å¦‚æœä½ æ¥å—å®éªŒå®¤é›†ä¸­åŒ–ï¼ˆå³äº‘å®éªŒå®¤ï¼Œcloud labsï¼‰æ„å‘³ç€ä½ å¯ä»¥æœ€é«˜æ•ˆåœ°ä½¿ç”¨å®éªŒå®¤æœºå™¨äººâ€”â€”è¿™ä¼¼ä¹æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªç›¸å½“æ²¡æœ‰äº‰è®®çš„è®ºç‚¹â€”â€”è¿™ä¹Ÿæ„å‘³ç€ä½ è¶Šæ·±å…¥è¿™ä¸ªæ–¹å‘ï¼Œä½ å°±è¶Šæœ‰èƒ½åŠ›å‘ä¸Šæ¸¸å‚ç›´æ•´åˆã€‚å¦‚æœä½ è¿è¡Œçš„å®éªŒè¶³å¤Ÿå¤šï¼Œä½¿ä½ çš„æœºå™¨äººæŒç»­è¿è½¬ï¼Œä½ å°±æœ‰ç†ç”±è‡ªå·±ç”Ÿäº§è¯•å‰‚ã€‚å¦‚æœä½ è‡ªå·±ç”Ÿäº§è¯•å‰‚ï¼Œä½ çš„å•æ¬¡å®éªŒæˆæœ¬å°±ä¼šä¸‹é™ã€‚å¦‚æœä½ çš„å•æ¬¡å®éªŒæˆæœ¬ä¸‹é™ï¼Œä½ å°±å¯ä»¥æä¾›æ›´ä½çš„ä»·æ ¼ã€‚å¦‚æœä½ æä¾›æ›´ä½çš„ä»·æ ¼ï¼Œä½ å°±ä¼šå¸å¼•æ›´å¤šéœ€æ±‚ã€‚å¦‚æœä½ å¸å¼•æ›´å¤šéœ€æ±‚ï¼Œä½ çš„æœºå™¨äººå°±ä¼šæ›´å¿™ã€‚å¦‚æœä½ çš„æœºå™¨äººæ›´å¿™ï¼Œä½ å°±æœ‰ç†ç”±ç”Ÿäº§æ›´å¤šçš„è‡ªæœ‰æŠ•å…¥ã€‚å¦‚æ­¤å¾ªç¯ï¼Œæ°¸æ— æ­¢å¢ƒï¼Œç›´åˆ°ä½ åå™¬æ•´ä¸ªå¸‚åœºï¼Œç”Ÿç‰©å­¦å®éªŒå˜å¾—æå…¶å»‰ä»·å’Œç®€å•ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªäººéƒ½èƒ½å‚ä¸å…¶ä¸­ã€‚

Iâ€™m not a scientist, but I can imagine how this sort of model could apply to other areas of scientific research as well â€” chemistry, materials research, etc.

æˆ‘ä¸æ˜¯ç§‘å­¦å®¶ï¼Œä½†æˆ‘å¯ä»¥æƒ³è±¡è¿™ç§æ¨¡å¼å¦‚ä½•ä¹Ÿèƒ½é€‚ç”¨äºå…¶ä»–ç§‘å­¦ç ”ç©¶é¢†åŸŸâ€”â€”åŒ–å­¦ã€ææ–™ç ”ç©¶ç­‰ã€‚

How far could this model be pushed? I opened this essay talking about car repair, which has risen in cost far faster than the actual production of cars. Iâ€™ve been in car accidents where the damage was relatively minor, but that nevertheless cost a large fraction of the entire value of the car to repair, due to the un-optimized, un-automated, labor-intensive repair process. Could we have some sort of large, centralized car repair facility, spreading the cost of its automated equipment (heavy industrial robot arms, lifts, welding robots, perhaps even metal fabrication equipment) across a huge number of repaired cars?

è¿™ç§æ¨¡å¼èƒ½è¢«æ¨è¿›åˆ°ä»€ä¹ˆç¨‹åº¦ï¼Ÿæˆ‘åœ¨æ–‡ç« å¼€å¤´è°ˆåˆ°äº†æ±½è½¦ç»´ä¿®ï¼Œå…¶æˆæœ¬ä¸Šæ¶¨é€Ÿåº¦è¿œå¿«äºæ±½è½¦å®é™…ç”Ÿäº§ã€‚æˆ‘ç»å†è¿‡ä¸€äº›æ±½è½¦äº‹æ•…ï¼ŒæŸåç›¸å¯¹è½»å¾®ï¼Œä½†ç”±äºç»´ä¿®æµç¨‹æœªç»ä¼˜åŒ–ã€æœªè‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–ä¸”åŠ³åŠ¨å¯†é›†ï¼Œç»´ä¿®è´¹ç”¨å´å äº†æ•´è½¦ä»·å€¼çš„å¾ˆå¤§ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬èƒ½å¦å»ºç«‹æŸç§å¤§å‹ã€é›†ä¸­çš„æ±½è½¦ç»´ä¿®è®¾æ–½ï¼Œå°†å…¶è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–è®¾å¤‡ï¼ˆé‡å‹å·¥ä¸šæœºå™¨äººæ‰‹è‡‚ã€å‡é™æœºã€ç„Šæ¥æœºå™¨äººï¼Œç”šè‡³å¯èƒ½è¿˜æœ‰é‡‘å±åˆ¶é€ è®¾å¤‡ï¼‰çš„æˆæœ¬åˆ†æ‘Šåˆ°å¤§é‡å¾…ä¿®æ±½è½¦ä¸Šï¼Ÿ

Itâ€™s not obvious to me whether this would work for car repair. Whether â€œAWS for everythingâ€ will work in a given industry will depend on the specifics of that industry, the costs and capabilities of the equipment available, and what scaling effects look like. If equipment is relatively inexpensive, and there arenâ€™t substantial economies of scale at work, I wouldnâ€™t expect this sort of production arrangement to necessarily make sense. A few years ago people were very enthusiastic about this sort of model for cooking, with â€œghost kitchensâ€ (å¹½çµå¨æˆ¿/äº‘å¨æˆ¿): commercial kitchens without any sort of dine-in option, preparing food for delivery-only restaurants. Some of the supposed advantage of ghost kitchens was that they required much smaller amounts of space that could be located outside of expensive, high-traffic areas (since you didnâ€™t need any sort of dine-in option). But ghost kitchens were also expected to have economies of scale. Multiple different â€œrestaurantsâ€ could be served from the same facility, possibly taking advantage of batch ingredient prep or high-capacity equipment. But while ghost kitchens are still around, they donâ€™t seem to have been the enormous success they were originally predicted to be. (Possibly this will change if food prep automation gets much better, but thatâ€™d be somewhat surprising to me.)

æˆ‘è¿˜ä¸ç¡®å®šè¿™æ˜¯å¦é€‚ç”¨äºæ±½è½¦ç»´ä¿®ã€‚"ä¸‡ç‰©AWS"æ˜¯å¦èƒ½åœ¨æŸä¸ªç‰¹å®šè¡Œä¸šè¡Œå¾—é€šï¼Œå°†å–å†³äºè¯¥è¡Œä¸šçš„å…·ä½“æƒ…å†µã€å¯ç”¨è®¾å¤‡çš„æˆæœ¬å’Œèƒ½åŠ›ï¼Œä»¥åŠè§„æ¨¡æ•ˆåº”çš„è¡¨ç°å½¢å¼ã€‚å¦‚æœè®¾å¤‡ç›¸å¯¹ä¾¿å®œï¼Œä¸”æ²¡æœ‰æ˜¾è‘—çš„è§„æ¨¡ç»æµåœ¨èµ·ä½œç”¨ï¼Œæˆ‘ä¸è®¤ä¸ºè¿™ç§ç”Ÿäº§å®‰æ’ä¸€å®šæœ‰æ„ä¹‰ã€‚å‡ å¹´å‰ï¼Œäººä»¬å¯¹å°†è¿™ç§æ¨¡å¼åº”ç”¨äºçƒ¹é¥ªéå¸¸çƒ­è¡·ï¼Œå³"å¹½çµå¨æˆ¿"ï¼ˆghost kitchensï¼‰ï¼šæ²¡æœ‰ä»»ä½•å ‚é£Ÿé€‰é¡¹çš„å•†ä¸šå¨æˆ¿ï¼Œä¸ºä»…æä¾›å¤–å–çš„é¤å…å‡†å¤‡é£Ÿç‰©ã€‚å¹½çµå¨æˆ¿çš„ä¸€äº›æ‰€è°“ä¼˜åŠ¿åœ¨äºï¼Œå®ƒä»¬éœ€è¦çš„ç©ºé—´å°å¾—å¤šï¼Œå¯ä»¥ä½äºæ˜‚è´µçš„é«˜æµé‡åŒºåŸŸä¹‹å¤–ï¼ˆå› ä¸ºä½ ä¸éœ€è¦ä»»ä½•å ‚é£Ÿé€‰é¡¹ï¼‰ã€‚ä½†å¹½çµå¨æˆ¿ä¹Ÿè¢«æœŸæœ›å…·æœ‰è§„æ¨¡ç»æµã€‚åŒä¸€ä¸ªè®¾æ–½å¯ä»¥ä¸ºå¤šä¸ªä¸åŒçš„"é¤å…"æœåŠ¡ï¼Œå¯èƒ½åˆ©ç”¨æ‰¹é‡å¤‡æ–™æˆ–å¤§å®¹é‡è®¾å¤‡ã€‚è™½ç„¶å¹½çµå¨æˆ¿ä»ç„¶å­˜åœ¨ï¼Œä½†å®ƒä»¬ä¼¼ä¹å¹¶æ²¡æœ‰åƒæœ€åˆé¢„æµ‹çš„é‚£æ ·å–å¾—å·¨å¤§æˆåŠŸã€‚ï¼ˆå¦‚æœé£Ÿå“åˆ¶å¤‡è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–å˜å¾—æ›´å¥½ï¼Œè¿™ç§æƒ…å†µå¯èƒ½ä¼šæ”¹å˜ï¼Œä½†å¯¹æˆ‘æ¥è¯´è¿™ä¼šæœ‰ç‚¹ä»¤äººæƒŠè®¶ã€‚ï¼‰

So for many industries the â€œAWS for everythingâ€ model wonâ€™t work. But I nevertheless think thereâ€™s a good chance that certain kinds of production â€” manufacturing, certain sorts of scientific research, other capital-intensive services â€” will be organized this way in the future.

åŸæ ‡é¢˜: SWE-bench February 2026 leaderboard update

SWE-bench February 2026 leaderboard update

The fresh results are for their "Bash Only" benchmark, which runs their mini-swe-bench agent (~9,000 lines of Python, here are the prompts they use) against the SWE-bench dataset of coding problems - 2,294 real-world examples pulled from 12 open source repos: django/django (850), sympy/sympy (386), scikit-learn/scikit-learn (229), sphinx-doc/sphinx (187), matplotlib/matplotlib (184), pytest-dev/pytest (119), pydata/xarray (110), astropy/astropy (95), pylint-dev/pylint (57), psf/requests (44), mwaskom/seaborn (22), pallets/flask (11).

æœ€æ–°ç»“æœæ¥è‡ªä»–ä»¬çš„"Bash Only"ï¼ˆçº¯ Bashï¼‰åŸºå‡†æµ‹è¯•ï¼Œè¯¥æµ‹è¯•è¿è¡Œä»–ä»¬çš„ mini-swe-bench æ™ºèƒ½ä½“ï¼ˆçº¦ 9,000 è¡Œ Python ä»£ç ï¼Œæ­¤å¤„æ˜¯ä»–ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨çš„æç¤ºè¯ï¼‰ï¼Œé’ˆå¯¹ SWE-bench ç¼–ç¨‹é—®é¢˜æ•°æ®é›†â€”â€”åŒ…å« 2,294 ä¸ªçœŸå®ä¸–ç•Œæ¡ˆä¾‹ï¼Œæ¥è‡ª 12 ä¸ªå¼€æºä»“åº“ï¼šdjango/django (850)ã€sympy/sympy (386)ã€scikit-learn/scikit-learn (229)ã€sphinx-doc/sphinx (187)ã€matplotlib/matplotlib (184)ã€pytest-dev/pytest (119)ã€pydata/xarray (110)ã€astropy/astropy (95)ã€pylint-dev/pylint (57)ã€psf/requests (44)ã€mwaskom/seaborn (22)ã€pallets/flask (11)ã€‚

Correction: The Bash only benchmark runs against SWE-bench Verified, not original SWE-bench. Verified is a manually curated subset of 500 samples described here, funded by OpenAI. Here's SWE-bench Verified on Hugging Face - since it's just 2.1MB of Parquet it's easy to browse using Datasette Lite, which cuts those numbers down to django/django (231), sympy/sympy (75), sphinx-doc/sphinx (44), matplotlib/matplotlib (34), scikit-learn/scikit-learn (32), astropy/astropy (22), pydata/xarray (22), pytest-dev/pytest (19), pylint-dev/pylint (10), psf/requests (8), mwaskom/seaborn (2), pallets/flask (1).

æ›´æ­£ï¼šBash Only åŸºå‡†æµ‹è¯•é’ˆå¯¹çš„æ˜¯ SWE-bench Verifiedï¼Œè€ŒéåŸå§‹ SWE-benchã€‚Verified æ˜¯ç”± OpenAI èµ„åŠ©çš„äººå·¥ç²¾é€‰å­é›†ï¼ŒåŒ…å« 500 ä¸ªæ ·æœ¬ï¼Œè¯¦è§æ­¤å¤„ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯ Hugging Face ä¸Šçš„ SWE-bench Verifiedâ€”â€”ç”±äºåªæœ‰ 2.1MB çš„ Parquet æ ¼å¼æ•°æ®ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨ Datasette Lite æµè§ˆéå¸¸æ–¹ä¾¿ï¼Œæ ·æœ¬æ•°é‡å› æ­¤å‡å°‘ä¸ºï¼šdjango/django (231)ã€sympy/sympy (75)ã€sphinx-doc/sphinx (44)ã€matplotlib/matplotlib (34)ã€scikit-learn/scikit-learn (32)ã€astropy/astropy (22)ã€pydata/xarray (22)ã€pytest-dev/pytest (19)ã€pylint-dev/pylint (10)ã€psf/requests (8)ã€mwaskom/seaborn (2)ã€pallets/flask (1)ã€‚

Here's how the top ten models performed:

ä»¥ä¸‹æ˜¯å‰ååæ¨¡å‹çš„è¡¨ç°ï¼š

It's interesting to see Claude Opus 4.5 beat Opus 4.6, though only by about a percentage point. 4.5 Opus is top, then Gemini 3 Flash, then MiniMax M2.5 - a 229B model released last week by Chinese lab MiniMax. GLM-5, Kimi K2.5 and DeepSeek V3.2 are three more Chinese models that make the top ten as well.

æœ‰è¶£çš„æ˜¯ï¼ŒClaude Opus 4.5 å‡»è´¥äº† Opus 4.6ï¼Œå°½ç®¡åªé¢†å…ˆçº¦ä¸€ä¸ªç™¾åˆ†ç‚¹ã€‚4.5 Opus ä½å±…æ¦œé¦–ï¼Œå…¶æ¬¡æ˜¯ Gemini 3 Flashï¼Œç„¶åæ˜¯ MiniMax M2.5â€”â€”è¿™æ˜¯ç”±ä¸­å›½å®éªŒå®¤ MiniMax ä¸Šå‘¨å‘å¸ƒçš„ 229B å‚æ•°æ¨¡å‹ã€‚GLM-5ã€Kimi K2.5 å’Œ DeepSeek V3.2 æ˜¯å¦å¤–ä¸‰æ¬¾è¿›å…¥å‰åçš„ä¸­å›½æ¨¡å‹ã€‚

OpenAI's GPT-5.2 is their highest performing model at position 6, but it's worth noting that their best coding model, GPT-5.3-Codex, is not represented - maybe because it's not yet available in the OpenAI API.

OpenAI çš„ GPT-5.2 æ˜¯å…¶è¡¨ç°æœ€ä½³çš„æ¨¡å‹ï¼Œæ’åç¬¬ 6ï¼Œä½†å€¼å¾—æ³¨æ„çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œä»–ä»¬æœ€ä¼˜ç§€çš„ç¼–ç¨‹æ¨¡å‹ GPT-5.3-Codex å¹¶æœªå‡ºç°åœ¨æ¦œå•ä¸­â€”â€”å¯èƒ½æ˜¯å› ä¸ºå®ƒå°šæœªåœ¨ OpenAI API ä¸­å¼€æ”¾ã€‚

This benchmark uses the same system prompt for every model, which is important for a fair comparison but does mean that the quality of the different harnesses or optimized prompts is not being measured here.

è¯¥åŸºå‡†æµ‹è¯•å¯¹æ¯ä¸ªæ¨¡å‹ä½¿ç”¨ç›¸åŒçš„ system promptï¼ˆç³»ç»Ÿæç¤ºè¯ï¼‰ï¼Œè¿™å¯¹å…¬å¹³æ¯”è¾ƒå¾ˆé‡è¦ï¼Œä½†è¿™ä¹Ÿæ„å‘³ç€æ­¤å¤„å¹¶æœªè¡¡é‡ä¸åŒæµ‹è¯•æ¡†æ¶ï¼ˆharnessesï¼‰æˆ–ä¼˜åŒ–æç¤ºè¯çš„è´¨é‡ã€‚

The chart above is a screenshot from the SWE-bench website, but their charts don't include the actual percentage values visible on the bars. I successfully used Claude for Chrome to add these - transcript here. My prompt sequence included:

ä¸Šå›¾æ¥è‡ª SWE-bench ç½‘ç«™çš„æˆªå›¾ï¼Œä½†ä»–ä»¬çš„å›¾è¡¨é»˜è®¤å¹¶ä¸æ˜¾ç¤ºæŸ±çŠ¶æ¡ä¸Šçš„å…·ä½“ç™¾åˆ†æ¯”æ•°å€¼ã€‚æˆ‘æˆåŠŸä½¿ç”¨ Claude for Chrome æ·»åŠ äº†è¿™äº›æ•°å€¼â€”â€”å¯¹è¯è®°å½•åœ¨æ­¤ã€‚æˆ‘çš„æç¤ºè¯åºåˆ—åŒ…æ‹¬ï¼š

çœ‹åˆ°é‚£äº›æŸ±çŠ¶å›¾äº†å—ï¼Ÿæˆ‘å¸Œæœ›å®ƒä»¬åœ¨æ¯ä¸ªæŸ±å­ä¸Šæ˜¾ç¤ºç™¾åˆ†æ¯”ï¼Œè¿™æ ·æˆ‘èƒ½æˆªå–æ›´å¥½çš„æˆªå›¾ï¼Œè¯·æŒ‰æ­¤ä¿®æ”¹é¡µé¢

item.title: [ç¿»è¯‘] Simon Willison: åšå®¢ä¸é€šè®¯èµåŠ©å®éªŒ
item.description:
æ ‡ç­¾: #åšå®¢èµåŠ© #å†…å®¹å˜ç° #ç‹¬ç«‹å†™ä½œ

æ‘˜è¦: Simon Willisonå¼€å§‹ä¸ºå…¶åšå®¢å’Œé€šè®¯å°è¯•èµåŠ©æ¨¡å¼ï¼Œé‡‡ç”¨Troy Huntå¼çš„ç®€æ´æ–‡å­—æ¨ªå¹…ï¼Œåœ¨ä¿æŒç‹¬ç«‹å£°éŸ³å¯ä¿¡åº¦çš„åŒæ—¶è·å–æ”¶å…¥ä»¥å¼¥è¡¥æœºä¼šæˆæœ¬ã€‚

åŸæ ‡é¢˜: Experimenting with sponsorship for my blog and newsletter

Experimenting with sponsorship for my blog and newsletter

I've long been resistant to the idea of accepting sponsorship for my blog. I value my credibility as an independent voice, and I don't want to risk compromising that reputation.

é•¿æœŸä»¥æ¥ï¼Œæˆ‘ä¸€ç›´æŠ—æ‹’æ¥å—èµåŠ©ï¼ˆsponsorshipï¼‰çš„æƒ³æ³•ã€‚æˆ‘çè§†è‡ªå·±ä½œä¸ºç‹¬ç«‹å£°éŸ³ï¼ˆindependent voiceï¼‰çš„å¯ä¿¡åº¦ï¼ˆcredibilityï¼‰ï¼Œä¸æƒ³å†’æŸå®³è¿™ä¸€å£°èª‰çš„é£é™©ã€‚

Then I learned about Troy Hunt's approach to sponsorship, which he first wrote about in 2016. Troy runs with a simple text row in the page banner - no JavaScript, no cookies, unobtrusive while providing value to the sponsor. I can live with that!

åæ¥æˆ‘äº†è§£åˆ°äº†Troy Hunt çš„èµåŠ©æ–¹å¼ï¼Œä»–åœ¨2016å¹´é¦–æ¬¡æ’°æ–‡ä»‹ç»è¿‡è¿™ç§æ–¹æ³•ã€‚Troy åœ¨é¡µé¢æ¨ªå¹…ä¸­åªæ”¾ç½®ä¸€è¡Œç®€å•çš„æ–‡å­—â€”â€”æ²¡æœ‰ JavaScriptï¼Œæ²¡æœ‰ cookiesï¼ˆ Cookieï¼‰ï¼Œæ—¢ä¸çªå…€åˆèƒ½ä¸ºèµåŠ©å•†æä¾›ä»·å€¼ã€‚è¿™ä¸€ç‚¹æˆ‘å¯ä»¥æ¥å—ï¼

Accepting sponsorship in this way helps me maintain my independence while offsetting the opportunity cost of not taking a full-time job.

ä»¥è¿™ç§æ–¹å¼æ¥å—èµåŠ©ï¼Œæ—¢èƒ½å¸®åŠ©æˆ‘ä¿æŒç‹¬ç«‹æ€§ï¼Œåˆèƒ½å¼¥è¡¥æˆ‘ä¸ä»äº‹å…¨èŒå·¥ä½œæ‰€å¸¦æ¥çš„æœºä¼šæˆæœ¬ï¼ˆopportunity costï¼‰ã€‚

To start with I'm selling sponsorship by the week. Sponsors get that unobtrusive banner across my blog and also their sponsored message at the top of my newsletter.

é¦–å…ˆï¼Œæˆ‘æŒ‰å‘¨é”€å”®èµåŠ©ä½ã€‚èµåŠ©å•†å¯ä»¥åœ¨æˆ‘çš„åšå®¢ä¸Šè·å¾—é‚£ä¸ªä¸çªå…€çš„æ¨ªå¹…å¹¿å‘Šï¼ŒåŒæ—¶ä»–ä»¬çš„èµåŠ©ä¿¡æ¯ä¹Ÿä¼šæ˜¾ç¤ºåœ¨æˆ‘çš„newsletterï¼ˆæ–°é—»é€šè®¯ï¼‰é¡¶éƒ¨ã€‚

I will not write content in exchange for sponsorship. I hope the sponsors I work with understand that my credibility as an independent voice is a key reason I have an audience, and compromising that trust would be bad for everyone.

I've added the two new model IDs gemini-3.1-pro-preview and gemini-3.1-pro-preview-customtools to my llm-gemini plugin for LLM. That "custom tools" one is described here - apparently it may provide better tool performance than the default model in some situations.

The model appears to be incredibly slow right now - it took 104s to respond to a simple "hi" and a few of my other tests met "Error: This model is currently experiencing high demand. Spikes in demand are usually temporary. Please try again later." or "Error: Deadline expired before operation could complete" errors. I'm assuming that's just teething problems on launch day.
